Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with straight sides; underside decorated with incised representation of papyrus flower and two buds mounted on boat of Ra; pierced through diameter; glaze gone; greyish white core; worn surface.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie (probably)
Curator's comments: Scarabs and scaraboids with a motif of papyrus’ thicket depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions on scarabs and scaraboids (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 4-7). This scaraboid is close to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 98-99, type XXVIII, subtype A167-168, see especially A167 for this piece). Let's note that the motif on the underside is incised, not stamped, so it does not share the technical characteristics as defined in Gorton's type XXVIII. For related motifs on Naukratis scarabs and scaraboids: Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.681; BM 1886,0401.1603; BM 1888,0601.1605; Birmingham City Museum and Art Gallery 1888A195.4. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund). Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 5)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 99, Type XXVIII A167)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.033) (phase 3)
